title: The ultimate guide to PR | Emilie Gerber (founder of Six Eastern)
key_insights: For B2B companies, press provides second-order benefits like third-party validation, sales enablement, and recruiting support rather than direct growth impact
Position your company as taking on established incumbents rather than creating new categories - it gives reporters immediate context
Keep funding announcement pitches simple: amount raised, investors, one line about why it matters - avoid convoluted messaging
Offer exclusives to reporters and be willing to follow up respectfully 3-4 times before moving on
Cold outreach done well is just as effective as warm introductions - relationships help get responses but don't influence editorial decisions
Most effective pitches are three sentences or less - longer pitches tend to perform worse
Use controversial or contrarian angles to stand out among similar pitches on trending topics

guest_background.current_role: Founder and CEO of Six Eastern PR agency

topics_discussed: Second-order effects of press coverage for B2B vs B2C companies

How to craft effective media pitches

Finding and pitching podcasts and newsletters
Examples of successful vs unsuccessful pitch messaging
Press releases vs blog posts for announcements
PR agency selection criteria and pricing

Identifying newsworthy angles from mundane product updates
Awards and speaking opportunities as PR channels
memorable_quotes: No one ever gets this tactical in PR. There's just so much theoretical conversation and examining the big blunders, but at the end of the day, if you're a startup that wants to get coverage for your company, you need to know actually the steps to take to do it.
I'm of the belief that it does not matter as much as many people think it does... any good reporter is not going to be making their editorial decisions based on who their friends are.

You can get so in the weeds with your own messaging that you want to set up this massive problem statement, you want to make it a huge trend story, but if you're very straightforward and you're pattern matching, it's generally actually going to work.
frameworks_mentioned: Second-order effects analysis for PR ROI
summary: A comprehensive tactical guide to startup PR strategy, covering everything from crafting effective pitches and targeting the right publications to building media relationships and measuring PR impact. Emilie Gerber shares specific examples, templates, and actionable frameworks for getting press coverage without relying on warm connections or expensive agencies.
